This is a screwdriver designed as part of my final English project covering the creations of The Diamond Age by Neal Stephenson ( see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:10789 ). I created this because in the book the protagonist, Nell, prints out a screwdriver to use in an important plot point ( notice how I dodged spoilers there ). On top of its aesthetic value, this screwdriver can also unscrew large, not very tightened, screws.
To copy-paste my already written artistic statement:
The third project is a simple screwdriver. A screwdriver was made by Nell for use as an improvised weapon in The Diamond Age. In her case she modified the parameters of the screwdriver to make it as long and as sharp as possible, and sticking to the theme of parametric design, I included this feature. While I did attempt to make the screwdriver as sharp as possible, I ran into the resolution and strength limits of the Cupcake, so the screwdriver that I printed out is not very easy to use as a weapon.
Print it out and have fun!

This is a handlebar mounted cup holder I designed for my motorcycle.  The mount is meant to be clamped using 2 M5 bolts and locknuts, with the cup holder and swivel mount attached to each other and handlebar mount using 2 10mm M3 bolts, 1 12mm M3 bolt and 3 M3 locknuts.  There are files for 7/8", 1" and 1.5" diameter handlebars.
Instructions Print one of everything and attach using 2 10mm M3 bolts, 1 12mm M3 bolt and 3 M3 locknuts and then mount to the handlebars using 2 M5 bolts and locknuts.

Openscad I designed this using Openscad. The entire piece is customizable. The current handlebar mounts are for a 7/8", 1", and 1.5" handlebar, but you can make this to any size you want with the uploaded scad file, just change the radius value to the radius of your handlebars, render, and export as STL then print. Or use the customizer

I have lots rechargeable AA batteries, and a few things that require D-cells.  This will let those AA's work in the D-cell applications. (LED camping lantern, mattress pump etc.) and the AA's are small so you can carry extras and replace them as needed. (Yes they might not have the current capacity of D-cells, but it works pretty well for what I needed.)

I designed it to use the 1-inch brass paper fasteners. You can buy a box of 100 at an office supply store for around $4.
1) Print (took me ~50 minutes ord-bot 0.35 nozzle)
2) file the 4 inner supports to fit your battery. (2 minutes)
3) insert the paper fastener at the top, use needle nose pliers to fold the tabs out then back on themselves.
If I have time I have a few improvements in mind, but these worked for the weekend. I just uploaded d-5 which loosens the grip on the battery. (untested) ...

Use this thing when you have a bag on your passenger seat that sets off the "buckle your seat belt light". In my 2010 Ford Fusion if I put my laptop bag on seat the car thinks it is a person and alerts me that their seatbelt isn't on. This thing turns off that alarm and if you like you can attach a rope to it to hold your bag on the seat. Tested on my 2010 Ford Fusion, however, I don't know if it will fit in other cars or not. The part I derived it from said theirs fit most of the European models so chances are good it may fit your car. Note: this thing only fits the front seat belt clasps. The rear seat belts are wider so the design will need to be changed to fit them. Obviously do not use this in place of a normal seat belt when a person is sitting in the seat! EDIT: There is now a version for the back seat! Again it fits my 2010 Ford Fusion. This new back seat version fits the front belt latch on a 2008 Dodge Durango. It might fit your car too, let me know. Front Seat Version Fits:
2010 Ford Fusion
Volvo S80 2002 model Back Seat Version Fits:
2008 Dodge Durango
2010 Ford Fusion (backseat only)
I printed mine with 1 extra shell .27mm layer height and 5% infill.

description.text:
This is a very modified version of the original mount by M4nu310u5.
I was using HobbyWing X-Rotor 40A ESCs and wanted a clean way to keep them mounted while cleaning up the motor wires. Also helps protect the ESC and mount in the event of a crash. I think the result is a very clean install. Note that I remove the OEM bullet connectors from the ESC and solder the wires direct. The ESC doesn't fit nicely in the Tarot mount with the bullets soldered on. Holes may have to be cleaned up... a T9 torx driver works great to clean them up, lol. You will need to use shorter screws for the motor mounting plate so you can use short screws to attach the ESC mount from underneath.

comments.text: Could there be a version for the bigger one, Tarot 960 or the X-Series? They have some bigger motor mounts and just upscaling is not doing the work
comments.author: NielsM

comments.text: I don't have either of those UAVs so I can't help. Sorry.
comments.author: NielsM

comments.text: I like your version, good idea to reuse the nuts in the mounts, make sure that the screws aren't too short and use thread locking fluid so the screws of the motor plate won't turn loose. Have you used FreeCAD to generate the STL? If yes, it would be cool if you upload the FreeCAD source file too.
comments.author: M4nu310u5

comments.text: I use Alibre (now called "Geomagic Design" or something stupid like that), so I don't have the Freecad source. I can upload a IGES, step or solidworks file if that helps.  I actually downloaded FreeCad just to open your source. I was going to use it to edit it, but didn't feel like going through the learning process of a new software. I'm very familiar with Alibre so I exported yours out of Freecad to an STL then really all I used was the outline of the shape so I didn't have to measure it all up.  Even then, after the first print, I added some material to the edges to make it match up better with the shape of the Tarot mounts I have.

author: mbenson1

title: Enclosure for a DIY resistor decade with thumb encoders

description.text: This is a simple enclosure for a 7 digit resistor decade with thumb encoders. You can find more information about the concept and the schematics on the EEV blog http://www.eevblog.com/forum/projects/diy-cheap-resistor-decade-substitution-box/ It's really great and helpful both for development or education, especially when you're designing opamp designs, filters or audio amps. You can adjust any resistance value from 0 up to 9,999 MOhms. The tolerance depends on the quality of the resistors, but 1% types should do fine for most applications. The enclosure itself consists of two parts. You just need four M2.5x10 mm screws (or an equivalent inch-size) for the cover and two 4mm banana jacks.

This is a model of a Smart Wheel created as part of my final English project about the creations of Neal Stephenson's novel The Diamond Age ( see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:10789 ).
Here is the paragraph about it in my artistic statement:
The first project I created is the â€œSmart Wheel.â€ In the novel it is a wheel made out of thousands of legs that are able to act as a computer controlled suspension system. In order to implement this using current day technology at a non-prohibitive cost some corners were cut. One is the complexity of the wheel's spokes; in The Diamond Age each of the thousands of spokes has its own processor and sensors, as well as fitting in a nanoscale form factor. In the project, this was cut down to a more simple rubber band system with larger and fewer spokes. The spoke and hub were printed with the Cupcake, and in the style of the Matter Compiler's interface both are fully parametric, with the size and number of spokes being fully customizable. As it has many holes, this is a relatively difficult object for the Cupcake to print, a limitation which a Matter Compiler lacks. At some points the spokes will jam, which is due to a resolution limitation of the Cupcake.

You will need 33 spokes and one wheel. The wheel is in the smartwheel.stl file, and should print out without any modification. To get these, either print out the single notched spoke 33 times, or print out the plate of unnotched spokes as many times as necessary. You may need to scale the spokes down, so prototype accordingly.
To assemble, get a bunch of rubber bands, and attach one to one end of each spoke. If you printed out the notched spokes, you can use the notch to make this easier. Then thread each of the ends through the smaller holes located on each side of the bigger spoke hole. Once on the other side, I secured the two ends using a wire crossbar, although nearly anything will work.
To improve performance, it will help to sand down the spokes and the holes they go into, as well as increase the number of spokes as much as your patience will allow.

This is a bracket to mount an external antenna when using external RF module. In addition to printing this, you need M3 screw, nut and a short SMA cable. The bracket is designed to sit in the location where the pictures show it mounted. To mount it on the other side, mirror the part. Print rotated 180 degrees in X or Y axis, the chamfers should be on the print bed to reduce or eliminate cleanup after print. The part I used to add a connector for internal RF module antenna:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:213959

title: GPS-Dome for Quadrocopter with FC 30.5x30.5 footprint (OpenScad, parametric)

description.text:
Update 24-OCT-2015:
  • Optional chamfer on Screw head hole added
  • Optional hole in top plate added

Small GPS-Mount to fit on top of a FC with standard 30.5 x 30.5mm footprint (CC3D, Naze32, Flip32). An additional "2nd level plate" can be glued in to place GPS or other components in between the FC and the top cover.
Many dimensional parameters are customizable. Support structure can be switched on/off.
Optional intermediate level plate should be fixed with some drops of CA glue to the 4 screw domes.
Is use this to fix a 808 keycam on top of my FNQ220 and another version to place a Ublox GPS module on my X525v3 quadcopter.

author: iSuat

description.text: Laser Cut cube tray. I like it 3 x 12 cubes (other people do it 3 x 11). The reason I like the extra column is because in some situations you can return a cube to its owner and put the cube in a different row from the one it came from (example: you make a friend, exchange cubes, break the friendship, now the cube returns to you and you put in any row, potentially filling all 12). I also like to cut a base (without holes) and glue below. Then use two of them and two rubber bands to store them for the next game. More details on my website. http://www.funelements.com/ If you prefer me to print them out for you, check out my Etsy storefront.

Notes: It works like a charm

My goal is to archive and share the work of my math students.   Scanning their tests, quizzes and projects and then archiving them in a shared Googledocs folder.  Scanning all this work would be too much for one teacher so I require my students to do it themselves by using their own smart phones or this "classroom" scanner.  The advantage of this design is that the ipod is secured and that it is on a wifi network (so students don't need to use their personal data).  There are many good scanner apps that are both free or have pay versions.  I am using Scanner Pro.  I also have installed "airscanner"  (found here - //www.qrayon.com/home/airscanner/).  This makes the stand into a wireless document camera that transmits to a browser.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Notes: Material needed: ipod touch 5th generation (or an old iphone). 4 sheets 1/8"x12"x12" clear acrylic. 1 sheet 1/8"x12"x12" dark acrylic (provides contrasting border for scanning). 1 sheet 1/8"x12"x12 birch plywood. 1" bolts with washer and nuts (4) for securing the ipod to the top. Red is vector cuts. Blue is raster cuts. The base with the large "x" is in blue acrylic and the same size base (without finger joints) was cut in 1/8" birch plywood.

author: cgoss

description.text:
Yo, this is my 1st upload to Thingiverse (love this place!).  We still use multitudes of Motorola walkie-talkies called TalkAbout's that use a unique belt clip that is hard to track down, priced far too high and unfortunately break way too easily.  I sat down yesterday and designed my own clip using broken remains and my trusty cheap caliper.  I was excited when after my 4th proto print I had a functioning 3 piece kit that seems to be working wonderfully!  I wanted to try sharing it just incase someone else has an investment in these units and needs additional clips.  This kit includes the belt loop clip, plastic spring and sliding jacket that all snap together after printing and will keep your walkie close for dispatching your ever-so important RF communications (or just make it look like you have "people"). 
This was printed from a TOM Mk6 plastruder running 1.75mm nuclear green filament equipped with an ABP

You should be good to go, I have included the following files: Sketchup file for single clip
STL file for single clip
Sketchup file for 3 clips positioned properly to print even on the automated build platform
STL file for 3 clips positioned properly to print even on the automated build platform I had to print using "full support" since no matter how I positioned the pieces there are "free air" parts that needed support. MakeOn peeps!

comments.text: God those clips are cheap. Both mine already broke. Im gonna see If I can do a rework of the design that is less prone to breaking.

description.text: Need a waterproof enclosure for your small project and want to have a nice control panel feel? If it will fit in an Otterbox 2000, you can lasercut this plate template to fit inside the base, supported by the interior ledge! There's room underneath to hide your Arduino, Teensy or Pi (without ethernet), plus a small battery. To test the spacing on this one I've added a basic potentiometer and some Radioshack buttons. The knob on the pot just barely makes contact with the top lid when the case is closed. If you use clear acrylic, you can etch the underside in reverse, which will protect the labels. It won't hide the wiring mess, but perhaps you like the "skeleton clock" look.

author: luisfcorreia

description.text:
Crying angel head.
Michelangelo?

This project provides a portable case for Raspberry Pi 2 or B+ in the form similar to a Star Trek TOS "Tricorder". The inspiration was from:
  • A need for a solid and durable form factor for a portable RPi case with display.
  • Several very good Star Trek NexGen tricolor case projects here on Thingiverse.
  • Hackaday.io project by Rob Vincent that uses a toy case.
    • This design has a swivel top for a Swainsmart 2.4" TFT 240x320 display. It has plenty of room for an internal battery, speaker, and a spot for small sensors/GPIO projects (my pictures include a GPS). To Do:
  • The swivel assembly needs work, it is difficult to assemble and potentially fragile. Perhaps pins added from the outside in, instead of the inside out.
    (Tried - was worse than wood/metal pins, so widened swivel holes to .14 radius).
  • (Done) Change from glue only assembly to a less permanent screw together design.
    • I've marked it complete, but I still might tinker with it.

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Notes: Print the right wall with Y-axis rotated 90 degrees.
Print the cover with the X-axis rotated 90 degrees.
Print the left wall with the Y-axis rotated 270 degrees.
Print the top with the X-axis rotated 180 degrees. Detailed directions attached.

Materials Note: Raspberry Pi 2
Sainsmart 2.4TFT 240x320 Display
-Note: Perhaps mods for Adafruit PiTFT 2.4” HAT Mini Kit
(4) 1/2” Standoffs and mounting hardware
SPST Switch
USB to Mini-USB Cable
USB Universal Power Battery Pack
(Optional: Parallax PMB-648 SiRF Module)
(Optional: USB 802.1 Wireless Network adapter)
16G SMC Memory Card
Stereo Headphones or small speaker with headphone jack.
Number 4 x 1/2 Wood Screws
1/4" Wood Dowel or Metal Rod (preferred) Construction Notes:
  • Print the base (make sure the sides are flat), mount the standoffs and then mount the board.
  • Connect the display cabling shown below:
    • Connections for SainSmart 2.4” TFT Display to RPi B (40-pin):
    LCD Name Driver Name RPi Name RPi Pin
    Vcc \ \ 2 (Vcc Bus)
    Gnd \ Gnd 6
    RS dc GPIO3 5
    WR wr GPIO2 3
    RD \ 3.3V 1
    DB8 db00 GPIO5 29
    DB9 db01 GPIO6 31
    DB10 db02 GPIO18 12
    DB11 db03 GPIO23 16
    DB12 db04 GPIO24 18
    DB13 db05 GPIO25 22
    DB14 db06 GPIO8 24
    DB15 db07 GPIO12 32
    CS cs GPIO27 13
    REST reset GPIO17 11
    LED led GPIO4 (or Vcc Bus) 7 via transistor to Vcc
    ———————————————————————
    Touch Screen Inputs
    T_CLK SCLK 23
    T_DIN MOSI 19
    T_DOUT MISO 21
    T_CS CEI 26
    T_IRQ GPIO16 36
    ——————Removed as it requires too much current ————————————————
    Parallax PMB-648 SiRF (GPS) Module
    Pin 1 on GPS (Yellow/TTL TX) to Pin 10 on P1 connector of Rip
    Pin 2 on GPS (Blue/TTL RX) to Pin 8 on P1 connector of RPi
    Pin 3 on GPS (Red/Vcc) to Pin 2 or Pin 4 on P1 connector of RPi
    Pin 4 on GPS (Black/Gnd) to Pin 6 or Pin 9 on P1 connector of RPi
    —————————————————————------------------------------
    Recommend that the following connections be extended to the module bay (and marked):
    Pin 8: RX (for GPS or serial)
    Pin 10: TX (for GPS or serial)
    Pin 3: +5Vcc
    Pin 38: GPIO 20 (for other projects)
    Pin 39: Gnd
    Pin 40: GPIO 21 (for other projects) It is strongly recommended to verify all hardware at this time:
  • Charge up the battery pack several times.
  • Verify the power switch functions correctly.
  • Perform the initial install/uipdate of OS and Display.
  • Print the right wall with Y-axis rotated 90 degrees.
  • The power switch can be mounted to the inside of the “Module Bay”.
  • Print the cover with the X-axis rotated 90 degrees.
  • Drill out the mounting holes for the cover in the right wall.
  • Plug in the USB Power Cord and Headphone jack, then screw the right wall to the base.
  • Insert the USB Battery Pack in the Battery Bay and use clay or putty to affix the pack in the bay so that the power connection can match up on the port on the left side.
  • Print the left wall with the Y-axis rotated 270 degrees.
  • Glue the left wall to the case.
  • Print the top with the X-axis rotated 180 degrees. Sometimes the hole for the pivot pin will need to be cleaned out. While the design is a.25” diameter hole, practice showed it was about .2”. I used a sanded 1/4” dowel.
  • Slide the top into place and add the pins.
  • Screw in the display.
    • OS Install Notes: Do you updates:
    sudo apt-get update
    sudo apt-get upgrade ---------Add to /etc/modules-load.d/fbtft.conf (may need to create this file)------
    spi-bcm2835
    fbtft_device
    ads7846
    -------Add to /etc/modprobe.d/fbtft.conf (may need to create this file)-------
    options fbtft_device name=itdb28 gpios=reset:17,dc:3,wr:2,cs:27,db00:5,db01:6,db02:18,db03:23,db04:24,db05:25,db06:8,db07:12,led:4 rotate=90
    options ads7846_device swap_xy=1 cs=1 speed=1000000 model=7846 x_min=300 x_max=2400 y_min=700 y_max=3200 x_plate_ohms=60 pressure_max=255 gpio_pendown=16 keep_vref_on=1

add display to /etc/modules:
————
modprobe fbtft_device name=itdb28 gpios=reset:17,dc:3,wr:2,cs:27,db00:5,db01:6,db02:18,db03:23,db04:24,db05:25,db06:8,db07:12,led:4
———
add tft to /boot/config.txt:
dtoverlay=ads7846,speed=1000000,penirq=16,swapxy=1

description.text:
For GPS:
  • If GPS, disable serial port from raspiconfig.
    sudo apt-get install gpsd
    sudo apt-get install gpsd-clients
    • Add to /etc/rc.local with:
    “gpsd /dev/ttyAMA0 -F /var/run/gpsd.sock" Change to Headset jack:
    sudo amixer cset numid=3 1 Highest volume:
    amixer cset numid=1 -- 400 Playing a video loop to spoof a TOS Scanner:
    Jessie:
    sudo SDL_VIDEODRIVER=fbcon SDL_FBDEV=/dev/fb1 mplayer -vo sdl -framedrop scan.mp4 PreJessie:
    mplayer -vo fbdev2:/dev/fb1 -x 320 -y 240 -loop 20 -framedrop -zoom scan.mp4

title: Calendar Maker - Any Year. Lasers and more.

description.text:
Shown is a 2013 calendar that I made on a 40W Full Spectrum laser. I developed a program to generate and display a full year or an enlarged monthly calendar. Any year/month. Just input the year and either hit a month or the year button and the new calendar is made before your eyes in a fraction of a second. The calendar is rendered and it is all text. It can now be copied and edited into any application. Screen shots of the year and month mode shown. Design custom calendars with it. I lasered these calendars using CorelDraw, files are enclosed. The possibilities are endless. It can even be printed on a sheet of paper to hang on your refrigerator or use for your notebook. Enclosed are the following files:
  • The calendar generator program. zipped file, windows. A great tool to have on your pc. (Source code (c++) available upon request)
  • Regular calendar format in coreldraw (2013).
  • Circle calendar.cdr (2014), ready to print. To make a new year, each month will have to be edited separately. Cut, paste, resize, etc.
    • Note: the font (size and style) can be changed, but a "fixed width" font is always required. Have fun, please show anything that you make with it.

This is a simple jar with a polygon cap and a simple thread. I haven't printed it yet, so it is not tested.

This project started when I saw an article on the BBC about the local police force; An appeal to donate jewellery boxes so people who have lost loved ones can have items returned with "compassion" has been started at a police station. Posters were put up at Ely in Cambridgeshire asking people to donate boxes for rings, earrings, bracelets and watches. Family liaison officer Dotty Stott said she was sure it would make a "huge difference" to victims' families. "We deal with very, very sad events and in the process of that we return personal jewellery of loved ones to members of their family - that's usually done either at the hospital, or in our police property bags," said Ms Stott. "And I thought that's not very nice or very sensitive, so I had a bit of a brainwave and I sent an email out to all our officers in Cambridgeshire asking for any old jewellery boxes so we can return property in a nicer way. Ms Stott said through her own personal experience, she wished she had once received items with more "compassion" after losing a loved one, as opposed to "sign there for this stuff". I didn't have any jewellery boxes, but I do have a laser cutter, and anybody with a laser cutter also has a few square inches of scrap plywood or acrylic. I quickly put this design together, and I'm putting it "out there" for anybody else to do the same; contact your local force, send them a link to this project, and offer to make what you can. Construction instructions are here: http://www.instructables.com/id/RingBox/ The original story: http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-cambridgeshire-33751749

title: qharley's mostly wooden Greg's Hinged Accessible Wade's Extruder

description.text:
To tell the truth, I really wanted to cheat when making this part this past weekend.  Greg's extruder is now so well tuned, that it will probably be one of the first upgrades I'll print myself when my repstrap goes on line.
But, it is all about the journey.  And I had lots of fun hacking this extruder together
I do not expect anyone making this thing, but here are instructions for the foolish, or the brave (or possibly both)

1) Get a nice strong Maranti decking plank cut-off, and cut 2cm off one side (you have to cut twice to get it squared off)
Open Greg's extruder scad file, modify it to match your hot-end, and keep as reference.
2) modify the 2cm piece you just cut to match the hot-end configuration on screen.
3) Cut another piece of 8cm from the decking plank.
4) Place it on end on the 2cm piece, and mark the hot-end filament feed hole.
5) Using the large gear as guide, mark and drill though the plant to secure the center of the gear shaft using a small drill bit (4mm)
6) Use a 20mm flat wooden drill bit, drill into both sides, leaving a 1cm center piece - it will depend on your plank thickness.
7) drill though using 10mm drill bit.
8) From center of the shaft, mark 45deg to the bottom front (right) of the gear shaft, and from the shaft straight up.  Cut.
9) Use M8 threaded rod, or bolt, and mount the large gear to the shaft placing two 608 bearings in the 20mm bearing holes.
10) Place Stepper motor with small gear attached next to the large gear to mark its position.  Place it as shown in the photo.
11) Cut 45deg next to the motor mount the reduce weight, and then recess the motor into the plank to align the gears.
12) Glue the newly created piece on the 2cm piece using your favorite cold wood glue.
13) Mount the large gear - you may have to recess the bottom piece around the gear.
14) Cut slot for lever in base of extruder.  Create lever using whatever you have available - I used plywood.  See photo.  The 608 idler is held in place with a piece of M8 rod, and the lever held onto the shaft with a spring.  The arrangement of this will change...
15) Mark the drive shaft, and hob it using your favorite method.  I used the tapping bit in a drilling machine way.
The gears I had available gives me a highish ratio of 5.  The small stepper I had laying around will not suffer too much ;-)

title: Super Compact Pan Tilt Camera Mount

description.text:
This was intended for use on a quad-rotor project, although it can be mounted on really anything. I used two Hitec HS-55 sub-micro servos and it whips the camera around without any problem. Enjoy!
If you like this project, or would like to know more about 3D printing, check out my new book "The Makerspace Workbench" from Maker Media!

Print out each part and glue them together (this might require a bit of trimming as the tolerances are tight.) The camera mount is supported at one end with a 2-56 x 1/4" machine screw and the other side is supported by the servo horn. The assembly is attached to the base using the servo horn and two servo mounting screws.

description.text: 給甯齊～^_^
This was designed to keep the antennas parallel on a D-Link dual-antenna wifi AP.
You may need to adjust the size/spacing of the holes to fit your AP. As is, these are 6mm holes spaced 86mm on center. Obviously, this should be cut from wood or plastic.

comments.text: ehm, are you shure this is really what you want? Two antenna's are used as a diversity solution; the antenna/receiver with the strongest signal is selected automatically, also for the next transmission to that station. These simple antennas have a polarisation (in your case vertical), they receive less if the polarisation of the other end is off (ie, horizontal). Since you cannot predict the orientation of the client antenna, you can migitate this by placing two receivers at right angles to each other and choose the one with the best signal. Putting them parallel negates that and might possibly induce weird coupling effects that further reduce your reception.
comments.author: JelleBoomstra

comments.text: You raise some good points. In this case, the AP is positioned such that a horizontal antenna would cover about 15sqft of the 2000sqft area it's intended for. The hinges on these antennas are very weak, allowing them to slowly migrate away from vertical, unless restrained. So far, this addition has improved reception tremendously. YMMV
comments.author: JelleBoomstra

title: Plywood Filament Spool
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A simple parametric laser-cut filament spool design.  
Designed specifically for my Ultimaker's stock 50 mm ID spool holder, but with a slightly larger 250 mm OD  than Hafner "SD 200 K" 200 mm OD spools for holding about 1 kg filament.

The flange and core pieces are supplied as two different DXF files.  Pack them to fit your laser cutter bed and stock sheet size.  You'll need one set (of the six) core pieces and two of the flanges per spool.  I've included the CDR file for the (rather inefficient) 12" x 24" 1/8" (300mm x 600mm 3mm) plywood sheet layout I used.  These sheets are inexpensive and using one per spool isn't too wasteful.  
Use six M3x16 or M3x18 hardware to hold the spool together.  Alternatively you may glue the spool together with PVA wood glue for a cheaper solution.  Either method is a little tricky to assemble at first, but you will quickly become adept.  Some tape can help hold the nuts in the t-slots if you are having trouble - especially useful if you have small hands and can't reach inside easily.  
If you need to use imperial hardware you might like to tweek the source OpenSCAD file and regenerate the DXF paths to match their geometry.  Similarly if you aren't using 1/8" plywood (about 3.1 - 3.2 mm thick) you'll need to regenerate the cutting paths.  Plywood can be poorly controlled in thickness and it is worth carefully measuring your sheets before cutting to ensure the tabs and slot construction will mate properly.  
The kerf of the laser cut isn't modelled, but the design depends on it being non-zero, yet fairly small.  This shouldn't be a problem for any laser cutter, but a CNC mill may need adjustments for minimum corner radius.

description.text:
Here is a picture of a bee I printed for a buddy that has a cool spiral drill for the stinger.  
All files should print without any support which makes for easy assembly.  There are also pegs associated...I havent seemed to find the perfect tolerance for the pegs so some adjust ment may need to be done for perfect fit (sanding or clipping).
This was my first attempt at painting so, don't poke too much fun lol ;)
The head and the stinger will stay pretty well in tack with the pegs only, however I found that adding some fusion bonding epoxy worked well.  I also used the epoxy to permanently attach the wings to the back...it printed much looser than anticipated and will require some epoxy.

Another request piece,
A Anime I have not seen (and I do like Anime, but there is
a LOT of Anime out there!)
I took many design liberties to achieve the model.
In the original there is a glass dome which I simply do not
model but instead try to make the 'eyes' behind the glass show.
I tried to make this support free and as such it is not
entirely true to the original art.
the thin cables and the long antennea are omitted as printing them with current FFF
printing would not be sucessful. Hopefully this is "close enough" for the free model market.

not printed yet.
2 shells and 10% infill would be my
test as the head would need the internal support to minimize
holes.

I wanted to replace a Regulator Rectifier on a motorcycle and wanted a Mosfet RR. The common advise seems to be the FH012AA which I bought second hand for a good price.
Problem was I could only get connectors in the USA which, including shipping, would cost me more than the RR. So, I printed my own connectors.

Print the stl's, there is one with a two pin and one with a three pin configuration. Solder or crimp some flat push-on connectors to your cables.
Fit the connectors and cables in the printed housings.
Connect the assembled connectors to the RR. I would advise to watertighten the connectors with some silicone. Will post a picture when fitted on the bike.

description.text:
use LT XbyY.scad GT
(Replace LT with less than and GT with greater than. No matter what I do, I can't seem to get real less than/greater than to appear here.) Save the SCAD file into a directory in your library path. Add the use statement to the top of your OpenSCAD code. Then call XbyY() with an object. Use this module to replicate any other series of OpenSCAD items, a certain number across and another number deep. For example, XbyY(maxX=3,maxY=4,bounds=10,spacing=3) cube(10); XbyY(maxX=20,maxY=10,bounds=10,spacing=3) cylinder(d=10, height=5); XbyY(maxX=3,maxY=3,bounds=20) union() { ... } Note: because there is no easy way yet to determine how big an item is,
we need to provide the bounds, as well how much space is to be placed
between the items. These may be specified using bounds and spacing,
or separate values in the X and Y directories may be specified using
separate boundsX/boundsY and spacingX/spacingY. For example, the cube here has sides of 3 and 4, so boundsX and boundsY are set to those respective values. Similarly, we want 3 units between the items in the X axis, and 5 units between the items in the Y axis, so spacingX and spacingY are set to 3 and 5, respectively: XbyY(maxX=5,maxY=5,boundsX=3,boundsY=4,spacingX=3,spacingY=5) cube([3,4,10]);
These are the allowed options: XbyY(maxX = how many across,
maxY = how many deep,
boundsX = object width,
boundsY = object depth,
bounds= object width and depth, // sets both boundsX and boundsY
spacingX = space between across,
spacingY = space between deep,
spacing = space between, both across and deep // sets both spacingX and spacingY
)

title: Support for J-head on Printrbot Simple Metal

description.text:
I recently upgraded to the latest Alu Extruder V2 http://printrbot.com/shop/printrbot-alu-extruder-v2/ and found that my E3D and J-head hotends did not sit as securely as I liked.
So I created this shim to place below the mount.
It goes onto the neck of the hotend where it would be supported on other printer. The hotend is then inserted through the frame into the extruder and the shim, hotend and all is attached to the extruder with 3 3mm screws. This roughly holds the hotend in place while you then tighten the screw meant to hold the hotend in place. NOTE: I found that the screw holes did not quite line up well on my printer so I moved them and while I was at it I also added a mounting tab.
I have not redone the screw holes on the original mainly because I don't use it anymore.

Fusion 360 to the rescue I quickly designed this using Fusion 360. It was a simple matter of creating a rectangle the size of the area under the extruder mount, locating the 4 3.2mm holes for the screws(only 3 of them get used), create the 13mm cutout for the throat of the hotend and then adding a 16mm filler.
Got to love Fusion 360 for simplicity and ease of use.
I am a software engineer not a hardware designer and I have no problems creating stuff like this.

title: Flexible S5 Wireless Charging Case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a case for the Samsung Galaxy S5 that is made to work with the official wireless charging back cover. I have added other features like a path for the sound from the speaker to travel to the front, along with a spot in one of the corners for a lanyard to be attached. This case has already been printed out by myself and I use it currently. I have made different variations and this one seems to have all of the correct measurements and line up perfectly for the microphone, headphone, IR, camera, heart-rate monitor, charging port, and power/volume buttons. I printed it using Fenner Drive's Semiflex material, I like a little extra rigidity in my work, but I don't see why this wouldn't work with Ninjaflex at all. I originally attempted this with Ultimaker's Flexible PLA in black and although it did come out successfully, the layers started to split apart and didn't last that long, so I do not recommend that filament (I'm not sure if color matters in relation to strength).
Make sure to read my print settings in it's entirety before continuing this print! If you follow what I did you won't have any problems (unless you know why I was having the problems that I was having, in that case do it the way you know will work).

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

100%

Notes: Using semiflex:
-Extruder Temp: 230°C
-Bed Temp: 70°C
-Speed: 15mm/s
-Layer height: 0.2mm
-No Extraction
-Needs supports around the rim
-Used Cura for the remaining supports (buttons, IR, headphone, charging port, etc.
-Made on Ultimaker 2
-Approx. 9 hours in length
-STL File has wrong dimensions (1/10th of the size), the actual dimensions are as follows: 83, 13.6, and 146
-Corners were attempting to lift up after about 2 hours. I used Cura to create supports of anything over a 45° angle it created little squares by each corner, I heated up some of my non-flexible PLA with a heat-gun (a lighter or anything that can get hot enough to melt it) and stuck a small portion to all 4 corners to make sure it held great. I don't know why it wanted to separate, I had just cleaned and applied hair spray to the bed, but semiflex filament is new to me.

description.text: In the summer I began an experiment to determine if 3D printed PLA molds could be used to create wax positive for lost wax casting. My early experiments with simply cylindrical forms were fairly successful. Four part molds, 3d printed with support material, sanded slightly and a healthy does of mold release did well. Two part molds and rough plastic were not so successful. With this in mind I wanted to see if a complex 3D scanned part would also produce a respectable, lifelike wax reproduction for possible casting later on. This to me would be the magic bullet where we could short circuit the mold making process for foundry outcomes. I chose my 3D scan of the Lion Protome in the collection of the Art Institute of Chicago. I have adopted this lion as my goto model for 3D printing / 3D scanning demos and workshops. It's a great object to scan - and comes out really well in Recap and 123D Catch with 50 or more photos. It's also a good object to print as it is just steep enough to merit support material but often prints just fine without it. I think there's a lot 3D print designers can learn from ancient sculpture where the artisans of the day had to do a LOT with very little. Especially when it comes to unsupported overhangs and other details. Despite being very dynamic in form - there are no right angles here at all. For more info: http://tomburtonwood.com/2015/10/3d-printed-mold-making-pt-4/

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

As low as you want to go. Any lines will be read by the wax and will be in the final object.

Infill:

10 - 15% should do it. more the merrier of course.

Notes: Sand the rough parts from the support material. Fill in any holes in the floor or sides with soft material prior to casting process.

Rhino does not like meshes. And Recap / 123D Catch does not export NURBS / Solids. So what to do? Well it's not perfect but the workflow goes something like this.
Locate mesh / 3d scan inside a number of volumes, leaving ample margins top and bottom.
Shape these volumes to minimize the eventual amount of plastic used up in printing process without weakening the part too much.
Determine location of parting lines and use WireCut tool to split the solids into their respective parts. Try to imagine whether the mold part will separate cleanly from the model and whether there will be a lot of friction or not.
Create keys using nested spheres or similar volumes. Place as needed to lock pieces together when they are printed individually. Use Solid > Union and Difference to add and subtract as needed. Basically attach the smaller sphere to one face and subtract the larger from the other.
Save everything to a backup layer + lock it and hide it.
Run the Mesh > From NURBS Object command on each of the mold parts.
Run Mesh > Boolean Difference on each mold part, subtracting the model from it until each mold part reads with it's respective portion of the model. Make sure not to delete input with each difference command.
Check the part, hide mold sections - does it look like it will work? IF not add more parting lines, keys etc ( this is where backing up the first version to a new layer is super useful ).
Export each mold section individually as your file format of choice.
Print with support material (if needed).
Remove said supports and sand down any burrs.
Fill any holes with oil clay or another sturdy malleable material.

description.text: This is a Z-Limit switch bracket designed for a friend that was inspired by this object here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:781168 by pureluck. Other than some overall dimensional location points it was completely redesigned to fit around a Peter Stoneham linear bearing mount. Files include a print ready and oriented Cura scaled (CS) file and a native STL file. The native file is intended to be imported with scene units in inches and object units in mm's. NOTICE: I have uploaded modified files (10/22/15) putting the vertical holes back to the original 12.5 mm apart. They were too exact to the end of the trip switch allowing them to possibly slip off the end. The only remaining change from the printed image are the vertical holes are slightly smaller (by .066 mm) in diameter to give better grip on an M3 bolt. The assembly used two m3 x 14mm bolts to secure the bearing mounts. This leaves enough threaded portion to attach the bracket with two nylock m3 nuts. An m3 x 25mm in the vertical holes was used to hit the z limit switch.

No

Infill:

75%

Notes: Recommend 0.8 mm shell thickness.
No post printing work should be required.
The file was created using trueSpace 6.6.  Though not a remix of purelucks object I do want to give his design credit as the dimensional reference used to make this one.

title: QU-BD TwoUp Upgrade with 20x20m T-Slotted Extrusion

description.text:
Well, I've seen several projects to upgrade to the QU-QB 1/2Up using a more rigid chassis in order to get more stability in impressions, but in all them you have to basically invest even more money than the printer costs, and some of the cases you have to rebuild the machine entirely. Also the creator of this printer Quintessential Universal Building Device, now better know as Q3D, is out with a couple of upgrades to try to correct the printer problems, but to update you have to spend over $90.00 after shipping, and even to do the upgrade you take the risk of breaking one of those of delicate parts that make up its chassis. This has motivated me to do my own chassis upgrade reusing all components of the printer, only investing in the chassis.The project is worked mostly in OpenSCAD , and I'm doing all components including T-Slotted Extrusion bars necessary for the chassis, so in theory this update could be printed almost completely and only the screws would be required to put the chassis together. The estimated amount to change the chassis using aluminium parts should be below $80.00 if all goes as planned . I am open to any suggestions, this project will be open hardware and I will post the OpenScan sources files to the community. Thanks, // ----------- IMPORTANT ------------ // THIS IS A WORK IN PROGRESS!!! // ----------- UPDATES: Goals: 1) Use as many part from the original printer as possible.
2) The frame/body has to be sturdy and content every component inside.
3) the final cost must be under $90. The test is giving me: 220x175x165 (XYZ) that's an great improvement in the X and Z axis. I order most of the hardware in amazon, so far is about $56, I just need to order the nuts and bolts to have everything I need. I will print the parts this weekend to make measures and test.

comments.text: I see number of bars uploaded, whose file name starts with T20. Are they compatible with MakerBeam or OpenBeam ?
comments.author: Tony_921

comments.text: My plan is to print all the parts and the beams in my QUBD, so the beams should not be longer than 100mm, then will joint with a connector that I design, this should give enough strength to the frame to support some tests before using aluminum beans for the final structure.
comments.author: Tony_921

comments.text: The measures are for standard 20mm x 20mm T-Slotted Extrusion, in my test print it just fit right.  These have a design compatible with the MakerBeam but are not 10x10, and OpenBeam have a somewhat different form in their new version.

I wanted to use the Tinyflex Bowden Extruder to start playing around with flexible filament, but it was impossible for me to find the 30mm spring required, so I remixed it to use the 20mm spring that's widely available on almost any site that sells 3d printer parts. For the hobbed gear, google "Hobb-Goblin 5mm/8mm ID Drive Gear" or get it here

title: Ultimaker BowdenFeeder Repair Kit
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
You have an Ultimaker and your bowden cable popped out of the material feed mechanism?
Here is the solution: This clamp goes on top of the material-feed-mechanism (MFM)
Two holes must be drilled to fix it in place. FEATURES:
  • It can be mounted preventatively
    so that your wood clamp teeth don't break in the first place.
  • It has round edges, so you dont hurt yorself.
  • It has Internal structure and is printable in reasonable time.
  • It makes it harder to move the gear by hand and to get your fingers between the gears.
  • IMO It looks good.
    • The more elaborated background story:
    I destroyed mine by printing black PLA (IMO more diffecult than transparent white or magenta). The extruder-motor lost some steps here and there for a loong time (no filament scraping! the gear really jumped back). When it suddenly got worse I helped the gear with my hand a bit. But that was too much force then :S . I recognized the damage not before the extruder-motor started to pull on the electrical cables. That was a close call! edit:
    Roman Jurt made an alternative version http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:40544

If your filament is "hand-force-stuck" disassamble the MFM in place.
Temporarely reassamble the MFM with the bowden holder rotated by 30
so it will at least hold for this emergency print (actually this holds pretty well).
Use high fillrate (>= 40%) (70mm/sec => built time around 1:30min) NOTE: (edit: FIXED in v2)
As it was in the old version it pushed down the movable inner part of the bowden holder thingie too. I changed "zsteplast" value in the *.scad file to correct that. IMPORTANT:
The oval part has to be rotated correctly so that it slides in and won't be pushed down but instead self clamp the tube. I advise: skeinforge -> comb & skeinforge -> jitter

comments.text: Pushing down on the "movable inner part" is not a good idea. If you push it down, it'll release the bowden tube.

The formidable Ender Dragon is one of the largest boss mobs in minecraft!
After having to fight past Ender Men it seizes the opportunity to strike, swooping in on the player with an aerial attack.
The Enderdragon is a fierce enemy destroying blocks that get in its way.
Allow it to cause havoc on and off the screen by printing this movable model!
The printed model is able to move in many ways to strike a number of different poses:
-The front and back legs rotate
-Its jaw is able to open and close
-It can flap its wings
-Its neck and tail can move fluidly in all directions.
I designed this in SolidWorks basing it from shots of the dragon taken from different angles.
I've used 7 sections to form the neck and 13 to form the tail in this model, but feel free to experiment in your own models adding different numbers for different effects.
The model was printed off in black PLA then the tips of the wings, spines, eyes and mouth where painted to add some more character.
Enjoy bringing the Ender Dragon into the real world with this very interactive model.

description.text:
This is my entry for the Assistive Technology Challenge. 
Millions of people are dealing with a verity of issues with their hands from arthritis, injury, or other illness. Such issues can make their silverware impossible to use.
These adaptive handles are designed to help those with dexterity issues use their ordinary household silverware without having to buy expensive sets from a commercial company.  These handles will work for anyone with weak grip, no grip (because it slips between your fingers) or thumb amputees. 
With a couple rubber bands, you can attach your silverware to the base of this handle. This will let you use your silverware without a strong grip or thumb. 
These were designed by Stan Baldwin & Ty Lendit for #AssistiveTech the Assistive Technology Challenge.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2 - .4

Infill:

0-5%

Notes: 15% supports, your choice to raft or brim to build plate. Because it is used for silverware, ABS or Nylon preferred, but PLA will work as well. Trim and sand smooth any edges left from a brim or raft. Hand wash only in warm soapy water. 2 hr print time at .4 mm resolution.

How to print This was designed in AutoCAD 2014. This was inspired by other silverware tools found through Thingiverse. I wanted something that could be held with no grip in the hand. This was to help anyone with dexterity issues that made holding normal silverware difficult. This design is also useful to anyone who breaks their fingers and is wearing a cast.
This design fits between the pointer and small finger to support silverware. I worked with Ty Lendit to finalize the design in AutoCAD. This is sized to fit my hand, and you can easily scale it up or down to fit the width of your own hand. Measure the outside distance between your middle and ring finger to give you the size to scale to. The original distance is 45 mm wide. Give yourself 2-3 mm room for your fingers as well.

Use in the hand This is designed to fit into the hand with no griping strength required. By sliding between the small and pointer fingers, you use the hands natural resistance to hold onto the handle. This can be used without the thumb, which helps any thumb amputees. You can use standard rubber bands to attach this handle to your silverware. This set is designed for left and right hand, so you can use a knife and fork with this handle set. This is designed to hold silverware as close to normal as possible.

So since high school golf is just around the corner, I decided to design an Ultimate Golf Green Tool that my players could carry with them and that I could remake after they lose it (I am positive that this will happen). This tool is designed for on-the-green maintenance as well as ball marking. The ball marker easily snaps into the divot repair tool as well as inserts into the green with ease.
I scaled the tool up 150% to what I think is the proper size, but feel free to play around with this. I recommend printing the tool at 100% fill to ensure no damage when working on the deeper divots.

Assembly instructions Place the RPi upside down into the cover. Line up the spacer with the screw holes, so there's a gap between the X and RPi. Position the cover so the hook is facing the ethernet port of the RPi. A portion of the bottom of the RPi should still be visible.

description.text:
This is the 250 size ducted octocopter I built for the hobbyking beer lift. unfortunately I didn't have as big motors lying around as some of the entrants and my scales werent visible after compressing the video.
It is printed in bridge nylon with zero infill. The booms are 16mm carbon tube the rest I used PLA but you can use whatever you like. I think they are all 25-35mm bolts used and some m3 threaded brass knurls melted into the PLA.
I am dismantling it for parts now so I thought maybe someone else would like to have a go at printing one.

zero

I've got a house full of beautiful door knobs. But these knobs were impossible to center in the first place and even once centered kids hanging on them caused them to wiggle loose and move up and down over time.
This destroyed my door paint (even though nice paint is a lost cause since I have kids in the first place). So, to fix my problem -- after repainting the doors -- I've created inserts to center the door knobs and stop the movement. I just installed 6 of these inserts in my house, and I think these are the greatest things since the invention of the shim.
I'm just waiting for you to agree with me and install them in your home. Let's see how long my new paint lasts...

Doesn't Matter

This set of handles is designed for anyone with dexterity issues. #AssistiveTech. These hold household silverware in your grip without closing your hand or using your thumb. This can help anyone with arthritis, amputees, broken fingers or other dexterity issues. Version 2 is designed for easier printing, and works with thicker silverware. It is also ambidextrous and made to use a fork or knife. It has a ledge deep enough to hold a pen as well, which lets you use this for handwriting. adaptive.spoon 6.2 has beefed up sides to take more grip and hold silverware better.
Adaptive.spoon 6.3 is designed to fit silverware better, with a backstop so you can use a fork.
V3 is another update to make it more printer friendly, with a bigger rounded edge and cleaner lines. The 3_silverware_handles file is so you can print all 3 and experiment with what you want. Designed by Stan Baldwin & Ty Lendt.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Nn_nxBsm_Jo

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.1 - .4 mm

Infill:

0-5%

Notes: 15% supports. Trim and sand smooth any rough edges. Use 2 or more rubber bands to secure silverware in place. To measure this to fit your hand, measure the width of your middle and ring finger. XL is 56 mm across (1.17 scale factor)
L is 48 mm across (1 scale factor)
M is 40 mm across (0.8 scale factor)
S is 32 mm across (0.7 scale factor) Designed by Stan Baldwin & Ty Lendt

Printing After printing, remove supports from gap. Trim and sand smooth any rough edges. Use 2 or more rubber bands to hold silverware to the handle. I found Size 33 rubber bands that you can get at the office supply store fit well, though narrower bands will work as well. Hand wash only in warm, soapy water. Designed by Stan Baldwin & Ty Lendt.

Design This was designed so you can hold it comfortably with no griping strength from your fingers. This is designed so you can hold it using the natural tension in you hand to have the handle hang from the top of your fingers. By holding it this way, you can use this handle if you have a cast on your hand, or have a thumb amputation. This was designed so a wide range of silverware can fit into the base of the handle. Version 2 was designed to hold thicker silverware. The bigger ledge in the back supports silverware that is found in dinners. Version 2 is also ambidextrous, so you have more flexibility when eating. This was designed in AutoCAD 2014 by Stan Baldwin &Ty Lendt

Use with silverware After printing, trim and sand smooth any rough edges. Use 2 or more rubber bands to secure your silverware to the bottom of the handles. When finished, remove and hand wash the handles in warm, soapy water. Designed by Stan Baldwin & Ty Lendt.
The picture shows S - XL handles printed in PLA.

And a 28BYJ48 stepper If your fish food's diameter more than 2mm, you will need a little Screw(prt0003) Arduino Code //#include "Stepper.h"
//#define STEPS 100 Stepper stepper(STEPS, 2, 3, 4, 5);//CHANGE TO YOUR PIN int previous = 0;
long interval = 7200000L;//Interval ,HOW LONG, 7200000L MEAN 2 HOURS
unsigned long previousMillis = 0; void setup()
{
stepper.setSpeed(80);
} void loop()
{
unsigned long currentMillis = millis();
if(currentMillis - previousMillis > interval) {
previousMillis = currentMillis;
stepper.step(3500); //HOW MUCH
}
if(currentMillis < previousMillis){ //OVERFLOW CHECK
previousMillis=currentMillis;
} }

title: Gilson Pippetteman P Beltclip with Tip Holes
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A little prototype for something I'd like to have in the lab! Gilson Pippettemans are very popular models for working with small amounts of fluid, which is pretty much what cell biology is all about nowadays. Having somewhere convenient to keep your gilson at the bench is no problem, but what about on the move? This design is supposed to be slotted into the Generic Belt Clip Adaptor:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1077 It has a 3cm gap to fit a standard Gilson (I think), 9mm holes for 1ml pippette-tips, and it's supposed to print the spine at an angle so the Pippette is held snugly at a sliding angle towards the belt.

First, print a belt clip adaptor:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1077 Then, print this item. Put the adaptor on your belt, slot the Gilson Holder in, and try it out.

title: PET Bottle To Sparkling Machine Adapter

description.text:
Make used PET water and drink bottles compatible with your sparkling water machine using this handy adapter. It is compatible with commonly used bottles with a 28mm thread that you can buy in most stores. The thread firmly grips the bottle, and the chamfered top part of the adapter connects properly to the machines rubber sealing, making it air-tight. VIDEO: https://youtu.be/b6aLm3s3nbY NOTE
This adapter is a concept model we used as an experiment to see if it was technically possible to 3D-print and use. We do not recommend you to use this if you are unsure of how the plastic and 3D printer you use will affect the liquid.

comments.text:
Well, I tried this three times, but they all seem to break at the junction between the two threads. It may be the machine I'm using (M3D) or the material (ABS) but I've upped the infill to max and even done an acetone vapor chamber to try to fuse things together but no dice. It's a great idea and I wish I could get it to work but because of the way the filament is played down, it just seems to be inherently weak when you thread it on to the bottle or into the sodastream. I had to remove the broken off chunk from my sodastream with pliers. Thank goodness it came out.
:(
comments.author: Oldbrass

comments.text: Tragically, i've had a little experience with the M3d. Had it for several months, never had a single decent print out of it, I certainly wouldn't trust it to print anything that needed a moisture tight seal. Worlds really opened up when i moved to a different printer. Best of luck.
comments.author: Oldbrass

comments.text: Thanks for your description of the print. In our experience ABS is a very challenging plastic to successfully 3D-print objects. The print settings, 3D printer and ABS type/quality can vary making the result unreliable.

comments.text: I had to scale in X and Y by 99% to get this to fit in my machine.  The PET fit (loosely) at full scale.  at 99% the PET is a little tighter, but functional, and the machine side fits.  Have not yet tested for pressure.  Will need to alter my machine to get a PET to fit.  I tried shrinking a PET, but they seem to shrink mostly in radius, not length, which is what I needed.
